newsitem.title: DUBAI: UAE takes copyright violator to court.
newsitem.headline: UAE takes copyright violator to court.

text.p: The United Arab Emirates has charged two men with violating copyright laws, the first such prosecution in the Gulf state which is trying to crack down on piracy, a local newspaper said on Monday.

The English-language Gulf News said the Dubai public prosecutor pressed charges against the sponsor of a computer shop, a UAE national, and his Tanzanian manager after police acting on a tip-off raided their computer shop in the city's commercial centre two months ago.
Police caught the manager selling a floppy disk of pirated software programmes and seized 12O discs and six catalogues containing a list of pirated programmes, it said.
The public prosecutor declined comment on the report.
A law firm representing the Washington-based Business Software Alliance (BSA) confirmed that legal action was being taken against the two men.

"This is the first criminal action on copyright piracy in the UAE. It was instigated by the software manufacturers themselves," said Hoda Barakat, head of the intellectual property department at Al-Tamimi and Co, the law firm representing BSA.
"Definitely it is a very good sign that the country is dedicated and committed to fighting piracy," she said.
"Software manufacturers are going to feel much more comfortable without the fear of copied versions" of their programmes sold for a fraction of their original cost, she said.
The first hearing in the case, set for October 23, was postponed to November 20 to prepare more documentation, Gulf News said.
If found guilty, both men could face a fine of 50,000 dirhams ($13,000) or more or between three months and three years in prison, the paper said.
Copyright laws were introduced in the UAE in 1992 as part of efforts to make the Gulf Arab state more attractive to foreign investors.
In recent years, authorities have stepped up the drive to enforce the law and regularly raided shops and companies suspected of selling pirated goods, a widespread practice in the oil-rich Gulf.
Authorities earlier this year destroyed thousands of pirated audio and video cassettes.

BSA, which groups leading U.S. software firms like Microsoft Corp, Novell Inc and Lotus, part of International Business Machines Corp, estimates software makers lost around $39 million to piracy in the UAE in 1995.
